Comment: I move up my king's pawn to free his bishop and the queen...
...my opponent opens with his queenside bishop's pawn to free his queen from the shorter diagonal, and possibly to spring a surprise...
...and I pressure it with my queen's pawn, also to free her bishop, and to give her more room to manoeuvre...
...but instead of capturing, he covers with his queenside knight's pawn, possibly to fianchetto his bishop...
...and I pressure with my queenside bishop...
...then he moves forward his king's pawn to free his bishop and the queen from another side...
...so I attack both pawns on the 5th rank, along with his rook...
...and he covers his king's pawn with his knight...
...so I give my queen some support from my kingside bishop...
...and as he moves his knight instead of his queen...
